title: 114_hr1950
content:
The Act is titled the "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" and it involves the abolishment of certain government agencies. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specified government agencies unless a law prevents it. The head of an abolished agency can manage its assets and liabilities for a year after abolishment. The Department of Agriculture and other agencies will be abolished two years after the Act's enactment unless Congress intervenes. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" requires the abolishment of certain government agencies, including the Department of Commerce, unless Congress disapproves within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specific government agencies unless Congress disapproves within 3 years. Other agencies can also be abolished if Congress has not passed a resolution against it in the past 10 years. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" requires the abolishment of certain government agencies within 4 years of enactment, including the Department of Education. Other agencies can also be abolished if Congress has not disapproved within the past 10 years. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specific government agencies within 5 years of enactment, including the Department of Energy and other agencies not disapproved by Congress in the past 10 years. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" requires the abolishment of certain government agencies within specified timeframes, such as 6 years for the Department of Health and Human Services, and 7 years for agencies like the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specific government agencies within set timeframes, like 8 years for the Department of Labor and 9 years for agencies under the Department of Interior. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" requires the abolishment of certain government agencies, including the Department of the Interior and agencies under the Department of the Treasury, within specified timeframes. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specific government agencies, such as the Department of the Interior and agencies under the Department of the Treasury, unless Congress has not passed a resolution disapproving of their abolishment in the past 10 years. Other agencies, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, are also subject to potential abolishment under certain conditions. The "Sunset Inefficient and Unaccountable Government Act" mandates the abolishment of specific government agencies, including the Department of Transportation and other agencies, 11 years after enactment unless Congress has not disapproved within the past 10 years. The House of Representatives' infrastructure includes agencies like the Department of Defense and the Department of State, which can only be abolished if Congress has not disapproved within the past 10 years. Any agency, except for the Department of Defense, State, Homeland Security, and Justice, can only be abolished if Congress has not disapproved within the past 10 years. Any agency, except for the Department of Defense, State, Homeland Security, and Justice, can only be abolished if Congress has not disapproved within the past 10 years. Agencies listed in subsection (c) will be abolished 10 years after their initial listing, and every 10 years thereafter if they still exist. SEC. 3. SELF-REVIEW OF AGENCIES.

    Before an agency is abolished, the head of the agency must submit a report to Congress justifying its existence and identifying any overlapping duties with other agencies.

SEC. 4. AGENCY DEFINED.

    The term "agency" is defined as an "Executive agency" in section 105 of title 5, United States Code.
